Title.evidence: Early Active Mobilization vs. Immobilization After Tibialis Posterior Tendon Transfer: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A power analysis indicated a sample size of 10 per group was sufficient to detect a 10-day difference in rehabilitation time.

Participants.evidence: 24 patients with irreversible common peroneal nerve paralysis

Objective.evidence: This randomized controlled trial evaluated early active mobilization versus immobilization after tibialis posterior tendon transfer for foot-drop correction in patients with Hansen’s disease.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was rehabilitation time, defined as the period from surgery to independent walking, measured over a minimum follow-up of 16 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using sealed opaque envelopes, and allocation was concealed until after surgery.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not possible for therapists, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We randomized 24 patients with irreversible common peroneal nerve paralysis to early mobilization (n=13) or immobilization (n=11) post-surgery.

Number_Analysed.evidence: No tendon insertion pullout was observed in either group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Rehabilitation time was significantly reduced in the mobilized group by an average of 15 days (p<0.001).
